title: Frances Lin
text:
üì£ Seeking opportunities in data science, machine learning, or AI roles starting in December 2025 or later!

I am a PhD candidate in Statistics at Oregon State University. I am currently a Software Engineer Intern at Posit Software, PBC (formerly RStudio Inc.).
Outside of work, I enjoy skiing, traveling, being outdoors, and watching thriller or dark comedy films and series on Netflix.

title: Dev, Data, Deploy ‚Äî Summer Vibes, Posit Style
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è work-in-progress
This summer, I worked at Posit (formerly RStudio), focusing on machine learning, software development, and more as part of the tidymodels team. I primarily worked on {filtro}, a filter-based supervised feature selection package in R.
My team at tidymodels is responsible for the creation and maintenance of the {tidymodels} 1 framework, a comprehensive collection of R packages for modeling and machine learning. It is similar in scope and purpose to {scikit-learn} in Python.

title: Experience
text:
Oregon State University

Doctoral Researcher
Sep 2021 - Present


Statistics / ML Consultant
Jan 2021 - Mar 2025
‚Ä¢ Provided consulting services across diverse fields, collaborating with faculty members, junior statisticians, and client researchers to support multiple PhD and master‚Äôs-level research initiatives.  ‚Ä¢ Effectively communicated statistical concepts to non-statistical clients and delivered in-depth reports on topics including simple statistical tests, advanced data modeling, application software (R, Python), experimental design, and data processing and visualization.


Graduate Teaching Assistant
Mar 2020 - Present
‚Ä¢ Assist with graduate and undergraduate courses such as machine learning III, missing data and causal inference, spatial statistics, stochastic models, computational statistics, data analysis methods I (hypothesis testing, multiple testing), II (regression analysis, model selection), III (dimension reduction techniques, generalized regression models), mathematical statistics I, II, statistical methods, statistics for engineers, and elementary statistics I.  ‚Ä¢ Teach R programming and discuss statistical problems during labs or recitations, hold office hours, and grade exams and assignments.


Graduate Project Assistant
Jun 2024 - Aug 2024
‚Ä¢ Assisted with the design and development of the course curriculum for spatial statistics.  ‚Ä¢ Applied a variety of spatial models, including kriging / Gaussian process regression, C / SAR (conditional / simultaneous autoregressive), and Poisson process / CSR models for simulation and applications such as housing price prediction, disease risk mapping, and forest and forest fire modeling.

title: About
text:
Thanks for visiting my site!
I am a PhD candidate in Statistics at Oregon State University. Broadly speaking, my research interests lie in
for large and complex time series data, with applications to energy forecasting and claims prediction. My other interests include deep learning and its more flexible and explainable probabilistic variant models (e.g., deep Gaussian processes, deep Gaussian Markov Random Fields) for space and space-time modeling.

title: Portfolio
text: No matching items

title: About
text:
PhD
For my PhD dissertation, advised by Dr.¬†Lisa Madsen and Dr.¬†Charlotte Wickham (now at Posit Software, PBC), I focus on the Markov MTD (Mixture Transition Distribution) models and the Bayesian NNMP (Nearest-Neighbor Mixture Process) models for time series forecasting and spatial prediction, as developed by Zheng et al.¬†and presented in [1], [2], and [3]. To achieve robust, flexible, and scalable modeling of time series and spatial data, both the MTD and NNMP models utilize probabilistic graphical model (DAG or Bayesian network) representations, finite mixture model structures, Bayesian hierarchical model formations, and MCMC algorithms.
My specific contributions include incorporating the copulas in the MTD model to capture more complex and flexible dependence structures; extending the MTD model to handle zero-inflated positively-skewed data; validating the models and assessing model performance through simulations and real-world data applications; developing a software package for the proposed models (using R, C++); and comparing the proposed models with other benchmark approaches, such as LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks (using PyTorch), to ensure robustness and accuracy.

title: About
text:
Master‚Äôs
For my Master‚Äôs capstone project, advised by Dr.¬†James Molyneux, I worked on selected spatial and temporal point processes leading up to Hawkes processes (or self-exciting point processes), which find applications in fields such as seismology, criminology, risk management, finance, etc.

title: Dev, Data, Deploy ‚Äî Summer Vibes, Posit Style
text:
The Journey So Far

filtro


tidymodels

title: A Great Summer of Dev, Data, and Deploy at Posit
text:
Behind the Curtain

PR #1: All the Things, All at Once
Week 1-2
My first few weeks at Posit were packed with learning and collaboration. I had daily meetings with Max and Emil. Max brings deep expertise in modeling,machine learning and software design, while Emil is highly knowledgeable about software development, from Git, GitHub Actions CI/CD (nasty stuff!) to Positron (a VS Code‚Äìlike IDE), and R‚Äôs S3 object-oriented programming (OOP) 2.
It‚Äôs tempting to jump straight into coding and testing, but Max taught an important lesson: before writing any code, it‚Äôs crucial to step back and think through the software design ‚Äî often, the real challenge lies in the methodology, not just the implementation. Meanwhile, Emil and I did some pair programming, which led to two great learning sessions:

‚ÄúEverything Positron‚Äù 3 
‚ÄúEverything S3 OOP‚Äù.



S3 OOP Brush-Up
Week 1-4
To be completely honest, while Xiaotian‚Äôs {mtd} 4 package is quite well-organized ‚Äî and I would argue that the most challenging aspect of extending it lies more in model development than in software engineering, I had little to no experience with R‚Äôs S3 OOP system. So here I am, pretty much glued to the Advanced R and R Packages books and poking around the {tune} package (plus {yardstick} and a few others) through weeks 1 to 4 to level up my S3 OOP game.


A Turning Point
Week 5
Max, Hadley, and I met to discuss the API design for the {desirability2} package. During the discussion, Hadley demonstrated some code using S7 5 and recommended incorporating it. üò± (That‚Äôs the ‚Äúface screaming in fear‚Äù emoji because I am both thrilled and frightened ‚Äî thrilled to meet him, but nervous about living up to expectations!)
To cap off an exciting week, Emil and I prepared and submitted {filtro} to CRAN 6.


CRAN Horror Story to Acceptance and Dual Branches
Week 6
I had to resubmit the package after making a few reasonable but minimal errors. Following the resubmission, the reviewer emailed me asking for revisions, with no further details. Gathering my courage, I replied back for clarification, and shortly after received an apology along with the great news that {filtro} is now on CRAN. üöÄ
The S3 branch was now on CRAN, while the S7 branch lived on as the development version ‚Äî many branches ahead in features and updates. In practice, though, I was juggling multiple branches, as I got used to merging, resolving conflicts, and navigating real-world Git and GitHub workflows, though I still find CI/CD concepts a bit abstract and challenging.


The Great S7 Migration
Week 5-8

Implement S7 for all scoring methods
Write S7 tests for all scoring methods
Refactor code using S7 (Max led the way!)
Refactor tests accordingly



Write, Write, and Write‚Ä¶
Week 9

Write, write, and write, (but not the dissertation kind!)

Though the internship was entirely remote, I had the pleasure of meeting the other intern, Jules, as well as other developers based in Europe and across the US. The most fun, though initially intimidating, experience was the tidyteam meeting, where the tidyverse, tidymodels, and r-lib 7 teams all gathered on Zoom once a month. It felt like seeing all the key people at Posit all at once 8.

Footnotes


Tidymodels https://www.tidymodels.org.‚Ü©Ô∏é
Though later, I found that that Hannah also has a deep expertise in these areas, and I learned a lot from her as well!‚Ü©Ô∏é
As a side note, I want to thank my co-advisor, Charlotte, for encouraging me to write and organize my dissertation using Positron. But, it wasn‚Äôt until this internship that I unlocked its full potential for software development and Git integration, though it was also Charlotte who helped me get this internship. ü§©‚Ü©Ô∏é
This is the package I build upon in my PhD dissertation. See Xiaotian‚Äôs package at https://github.com/xzheng42/mtd. My extended version will be available on GitHub in late December or later. ü§û‚Ü©Ô∏é

We‚Äôve considered names like {filter}, {filters}, {filtrr}, {flitrrr}, and {filtron}, but unfortunately, most of them are already taken.‚Ü©Ô∏é
The Comprehensive R Archive Network https://cran.r-project.org.‚Ü©Ô∏é
Some of the most useful developer tools we used daily, such as {devtools}, {usethis}, {testthat}, and {rlang}, were all developed by the r-lib team https://github.com/r-lib.‚Ü©Ô∏é
I also really enjoyed the weekly tidymodels meeting because it brought together people like Max, Emil, Hannah, and Simon, whose work was more relevant to mine. That said, I have to admit that sometimes I got overwhelmed by the many details involved in the many packages maintained by the team. Simon‚Äôs work on AI assistance through LLM integration, however, was quite intriguing.‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Dev, Data, Deploy ‚Äî Summer Vibes, Posit Style
text:
Behind the Scenes

PR #1: All the Things, All at Once
My first 2 weeks at Posit were packed with learning and collaboration. I had daily meetings with Max and Emil. Max brings deep expertise in modeling, machine learning and software design, while Emil is highly knowledgeable about software development, from Positron (a VS Code‚Äìlike IDE) and R‚Äôs S3 object-oriented programming (OOP), to Posit‚Äôs developer tools, Git and GitHub Actions CI/CD (nasty stuff!) 2.
It‚Äôs tempting to jump straight into coding and testing, but Max taught an important lesson: before writing any code, it‚Äôs crucial to step back and think through the software design ‚Äî often, the real challenge lies in the methodology, not just the implementation. Meanwhile, Emil and I did some pair programming, which led to two great learning sessions:

‚ÄúEverything Positron‚Äù 3 
‚ÄúEverything S3 OOP‚Äù.



S3 OOP Brush-Up
To be completely honest, while Xiaotian‚Äôs {mtd} 4 package is quite well-organized ‚Äî and I would argue that the most challenging aspect of extending it lies more in model development than in software engineering, I had little to no experience with R‚Äôs S3 OOP system. So here I am, pretty much glued to the Advanced R and R Packages books while poking around the {dials} package (plus {yardstick}, {tune} and a few others) through weeks 1 to 4 to level up my S3 OOP game.


A Turning Point
Max, Hadley, and I met to discuss the API design for the {desirability2} package. During the discussion, Hadley demonstrated some code using S7 5 and recommended incorporating it. üò± (The ‚Äúface screaming in fear‚Äù emoji because I am both thrilled and frightened ‚Äî thrilled to meet him, but nervous about living up to expectations!)
To cap off an exciting week, Emil and I prepared and submitted {filtro} 6 to CRAN 7.


CRAN Horror Story to Acceptance and Dual Branches
I had to resubmit the package after making a few reasonable but minimal errors. Following the resubmission, the reviewer emailed me asking for revisions, with no further details. Gathering my courage, I replied back for clarification, and shortly after received an apology along with the great news that {filtro} is now on CRAN. üöÄ
The S3 branch was now on CRAN, while the S7 branch lived on as the development version ‚Äî many branches ahead in features and updates. In practice, though, I was juggling multiple branches, as I got used to merging, resolving conflicts, and navigating real-world Git and GitHub workflows, though I still find CI/CD concepts a bit abstract and challenging.


The Great S7 Migration üõ•
Since meeting with Hadley in week 5, my weeks 5 to 8 were largely focused on implementing S7 for all scoring methods. I also spent a lot of time rewriting tests to match the new setup and helping with code refactoring ‚Äî with Max laid the groundwork with one method!
These four weeks were perhaps the most challenging part of my internship, but also the most rewarding. I had the opportunity to work closely with Max, who has played a key role in shaping high-level engineering work within tidymodels. I learned a lot just by observing how he approached problems, structured code, and made thoughtful decisions during refactoring. It was a steep learning curve, but being part of this process pushed me to the next level ‚Äî from writing cleaner, more maintable code to thinking more critically about software design as well as user experience.


Write, Write, and Write‚Ä¶
Week 9 and on is all about writing, writing, and more writing ‚Äî but not the dissertation kind!
working zone
The vignette pages for the tidy pages are phenomenal, which definitely adds a bit of pressure to deliver my best.
The package website is up running!
working zone
Though the internship was entirely remote, I had the pleasure of meeting the other intern, Jules, as well as other developers based in Europe and across the US. The most fun, though initially intimidating, experience was the monthly tidyteam meeting, where the tidyverse, tidymodels, and r-lib 8 teams all gathered on Zoom once a month. It felt like seeing all the key people at Posit all at once 9.
